articles.author: Dimpal Rajput
articles.description:
‚öõÔ∏è What is React?
A JavaScript library for building user interfaces
Helps create interactive, reusable UI components
Ideal for Single Page Applications (SPAs)
Powered by Virtual DOM for faster performance
‚úÖ Why Use React?
üîÅ Component-Based ‚Äì Reusable UI blocks = less code, better structure
‚ö° Fast Rendering ‚Äì Uses Virtual DOM to update only the changed parts.
üìçWhere and When to Use React?
A dynamic front-end (like a dashboard, social media, e-commerce site)
A SPA (Single Page Application) for fast user interactions
Reusable components like buttons, modals, forms, cards, etc.
Integration with other libraries like Redux, React Router, etc.
React is used in:
Instagram, Facebook, WhatsApp Web
Netflix, Airbnb, Uber, and more!
üåü Advantages of React
‚úÖ Reusability of components
‚úÖ Improved performance with Virtual DOM
‚úÖ Strong community and third-party support
‚úÖ Easier debugging with tools like React DevTools
‚úÖ Flexibility with different backend frameworks
‚ö†Ô∏è Disadvantages of React
‚ùå Fast-changing environment ‚Äì frequent updates and breaking changes
‚ùå SEO can be tricky in SPAs (Next.js solves this)
‚ùå Too many choices (state management, routing, etc.)
Thanks for reading! If you found this helpful, feel free to comment, share, or suggest what you'd like me to cover next. üôå
articles.title: What is React? Why we use it? When, Where & Pros and Cons.

articles.author: Micol Altomare
articles.description:
I‚Äôm a firm believer in lifelong learning, especially in a field as dynamic as Artificial Intelligence. So, when I heard about the Advanced LLM Agents MOOC (Massive Open Online Course) offered by UC Berkeley, featuring lectures from leading researchers, I knew I had to dive in. The promise of learning from the architects of tomorrow's AI, like Prof. Dawn Song and a host of industry pioneers, was too good to pass up. You can explore the course yourself ‚Äì the content is publicly available: https://llmagents-learning.org/sp25.
One lecture that particularly resonated with me was "Learning to Self-Improve & Reason with LLMs" by Jason Weston of Meta & NYU. His presentation was a deep dive into the cutting edge of making LLMs smarter and more capable. Here are my top 7 takeaways from his insightfu‚Ä¶
articles.title: Learning from the Future: 7 Insights from UC Berkeley's LLM Agents Course

articles.author: Tyler Johnston-Kent
articles.description:
So this guy ‚Äî Kenn White ‚Äî who‚Äôs apparently worked with PlayStation, Amazon, and all that, jumped into my comment thread on LinkedIn to basically try and school me about AI-generated mobile games.
I had said something simple:
Games on Mistplay and other mobile platforms are already being built using AI tools ‚Äî low-rated ones, fast clones, reward-based apps. They're everywhere. You just don‚Äôt hear about them because no one brags about them. But they make money.
Kenn decided to jump in and throw his status around, asking for proof, acting like that kind of thing doesn‚Äôt happen.
I responded calmly, explaining how I‚Äôve been building AI-assisted systems myself, integrating Firebase, procedural logic, and even using Unity just to output animations ‚Äî but doing the actual gameplay engine in JavaScript for speed and performance.
And what happened next?
He blocked me.
Here's his page if you're curious who got cooked:
https://www.linkedin.com/in/kennwhite/
What‚Äôs Funny About It
They‚Äôre not fancy. They just work.
And I‚Äôm trying to build the same kind of systems, just with my style, my identity.


TL;DR
Might turn the whole thing into a dev.to series on indie game engines and procedural mobile development with Firebase + JS.
‚ÄîTyler
articles.title: üí• Got Blocked by a PlayStation Vet for Calling Out the Truth About AI Games

articles.author: John Wakaba
articles.description:
POSTGRESQL DB IN PYTHON


A database is basically an organised collection of data that is structured and electronically stored in a computer system. 
  Postgresql 
  Microsoft SQL server
  Mysql
  Sqlite
Sql is the key cornerstone for the above relational databases. 
  A smooth integration with other programming languages such as python, R. 
  Data integrity. 
  Reliability.
  A proven architecture.
  Safely stores and scales the most complicated data workloads. 
Psycopg2 is the most popular Postgresql database adapter for python. 
In this article I am using python in a container environment.  Open the command prompt and type; 
conda install -c anaconda psycopg2
‚Ä¢ Conda Prompt is the terminal interface for managing Conda environments and launching tools such as JupyterLab.
We first import ‚Ä¶
articles.title: POSTGRESQL DB IN PYTHON

articles.author: Gaurang
articles.description:
Hi! I'm Gaurang. I‚Äôve worked extensively with Node.js in the past, and during that time, I spent a lot of effort wrangling with different async patterns ‚Äî callbacks, promises, and async/await. This article is part of my series, My guide to getting through the maze of callbacks, promises, and async-await, where I share lessons learned and best practices for writing asynchronous code in Node.js.
This article assumes you‚Äôre familiar with basic Node.js concepts, especially asynchronous programming constructs like callbacks, promises, and async/await.
Converting a Promise-based Function to Use Callbacks
Prefer Then-chaining over nesting
Often, you‚Äôll find yourself working in older codebases where asynchronous functions are written using the callback pattern. Node.js also offers a built-in way t‚Ä¶
articles.title: [Node.js] How to Use Promises in a Callback-based Codebase

articles.author: Maksym Kunytskyi
articles.description:
Lately, I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about technical meetings.

You know ‚Äî those syncs, standups, grooming sessions, ‚Äúquick‚Äù clarifications, architecture overviews, retro deep-dives, async that turns into sync, and everything in between.
How many of them do we really need?
I say this as someone who enjoys teamwork ‚Äî but I‚Äôm starting to believe we‚Äôre seriously overdoing it.
A ‚Äúquick call‚Äù often turns into a 30‚Äì45 minute rabbit hole.
Meetings interrupt deep focus. Even a 15-minute sync at 11:30 AM can ruin an entire productive morning.
Half the time, the same question could be resolved in 3 Slack messages or a Loom video.
The more people in the call ‚Äî the less productive it usually is.
And most importantly:
More meetings ‚â† more alignment.

Often, they‚Äôre a symptom of unclear specs, weak async culture, or trust issues.
Here‚Äôs what has worked for me (and the teams I‚Äôve led):
Write clearer tickets. Record short Loom videos. Share architecture ideas in Notion or GitHub Issues.
Not every engineer, PM, and designer needs to be in every call.
Ask: ‚ÄúCan this be a doc?‚Äù ‚Üí If yes, make a doc.

Ask: ‚ÄúDo I really need live feedback?‚Äù ‚Üí If not, write it up.
When developers are trusted to make technical decisions and document them, calls become rare and more impactful.
Don‚Äôt get me wrong ‚Äî I‚Äôve had great technical calls.

Collaborative design sessions, real-time debugging, or architecture whiteboarding can be amazing. But they should be the exception ‚Äî not the default.
If you're in meetings all day and wondering why you're shipping less ‚Äî this might be your answer.
How many technical calls do you have each week?
How many of them could be async?
What helps your team reduce meeting overload?
Let‚Äôs share ideas below üí¨
articles.title: How Many Technical Calls Do You Really Need?

Read more here.....

articles.author: idavidov13
articles.description:
üß™ Building Playwright Framework Step By Step - Implementing API Tests



  
  
  üéØ Introduction


API testing in Playwright focuses on directly interacting with web applications at the API level, aiming to validate the functionality, reliability, efficiency, and security of RESTful services and endpoints! üöÄ Unlike traditional browser-based tests, API testing with Playwright involves sending HTTP requests to the API and examining the responses, without rendering the graphical interface. This method provides a fast, efficient way to identify issues early in the development cycle, ensuring APIs adhere to their specifications and correctly integrate with front-end components and other services.
üéØ Why API Testing?: API tests are faster, more reliable, and provide better coverage than UI tes‚Ä¶
articles.title: üß™ Building Playwright Framework Step By Step - Implementing API Tests

articles.author: vrauuss softwares
articles.description:
3 ways to open SVG files as text instead of preview mode in Visual Studio Code.
context menu



Locate any .svg file
Right-click it and select Open With...

Select Configure default editor for '*.svg'...

Set **Text Editor" as the default
settings.json



Open Manage menu from the gear icon (‚öôÔ∏è)
Go to Settings

Open settings.json from the file icon (üìÉ)
Add the following snippet:




"workbench.editorAssociations": {
  "*.svg": "default"
}

GUI



Open Manage from the gear icon (‚öôÔ∏è)
Go to Settings

Search for Workbench.EditorAssociation

Click Add Item

Enter *.svg in the Item field
Enter default in the Value field
Click OK to apply
YouTube: Vrauuss Softwares

GitHub: Vrauuss Softwares







  
  
  Blog


Coming soon‚Ä¶
YouTube: How to Disable SVG Preview Mode

DEV.to: How to Disable SVG Preview Mode







  
  
  References



Reddit: SVG files open as Preview

StackOverflow: Unable to import SVG with Vite as React Component
articles.title: How to Disable SVG Preview Mode

articles.author: hiruthicSha
articles.description:
If I had a penny for every time a developer copy-pasted an error into Google or Stack Overflow without reading it, I'd be running a global datacenter by now. And don't get me started with this new LLM race, blindly following what the LLM asks you to do.
An error pops up‚Ä¶ and instead of reading it, your fingers are already firing up Chrome. Paste. Search. Click random Stack Overflow answers. Try. Fail. Try again. Maybe drop it into ChatGPT, hoping magic happens.
And somehow, this feels like debugging.
this is not debugging.  
It's reaction. It's panic. It's a habit. And it's wasting your time, your growth, and your ability to actually solve problems.
We've all been there. Stuck. Frustrated. The deadline is creeping up, tasks are getting reprioritized and all you want is for the damn thing t‚Ä¶
articles.title: You're Not Debugging. You're Just Wasting Time
